questions.text: Enzyme which is active in well fed state is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Explanation: • Acety1 Co-A carboxylase is the rate- limiting step of fatty acid synthesis. Fatty acid synthesis occurs during well fed state. Insulin is the predominant hormone during well-fed state. • Pyruvate carboxylase is the first step during gluconeogenesis. Gluconeogenesis is favoured by glucagon, the predominant hormone of the fasting state. • Carnitine palmitoy transferase1 is the regulatory step for fatty acid oxidation, which occurs during fasting.

questions.text: Second messenger for smooth muscle relaxation mediated by NO is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • A. cGMP (Cyclic Guanosine Monophosphate): Nitric oxide (NO) induces smooth muscle relaxation primarily through the cGMP pathway. NO activates soluble guanylyl cyclase in smooth muscle cells, leading to increased levels of cGMP. Elevated cGMP activates protein kinase G (PKG), which phosphorylates target proteins that result in decreased intracellular calcium levels and desensitization of the contractile apparatus to calcium, culminating in muscle relaxation.

  • B. cAMP (Cyclic Adenosine Monophosphate): While cAMP is another second messenger involved in smooth muscle relaxation, it operates through a different pathway. Agents like epinephrine increase cAMP levels via activation of adenylate cyclase, leading to activation of protein kinase A (PKA), which also results in reduced intracellular calcium levels and muscle relaxation. However, this pathway is distinct from the NO-mediated mechanism. 

  • C. Ca2+ (Calcium Ions): Calcium ions play a central role in muscle contraction. An increase in intracellular Ca2+ concentration leads to muscle contraction, while a decrease promotes relaxation. However, Ca2+ itself is not a second messenger for NO-mediated smooth muscle relaxation; rather, NO leads to a reduction in intracellular Ca2+ levels through the cGMP pathway. ​

  • D. Magnesium: Magnesium ions influence muscle function by acting as natural calcium antagonists, helping to relax muscles. Nonetheless, magnesium is not considered a second messenger in the NO-mediated relaxation pathway.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the type of reflex arc and sensory receptor for the flexor withdrawal reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The flexor reflex is elicited most powerfully by stimulation of pain endings, for which reason it is also called a nociceptive reflex, or simply a pain reflex. A painful stimulus applied to the hand causes the flexor muscles of the upper arm to become excited, thus withdrawing the hand from the painful stimulus. The pathways for eliciting the flexor reflex do not pass directly to the anterior motor neurons but instead pass first into a pool of interneurons within the spinal cord and only secondarily to the motor neurons.

questions.text: Regarding teriparatide find out the false statement
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Teriparatide is the synthetic human 34–amino acid amino-terminal PTH fragment [hPTH(1–34)], it is the peptide and administered by subcutaneous injection.  It is acting by increasing new bone formation. It is approved for use in treating severe osteoporosis in patients at a high risk for fracture. In postmenopausal women with osteoporosis, teriparatide increases BMD and reduces the risk of vertebral and nonvertebral fractures. Adverse effects include hypercalcemia, exacerbation of nephrolithiasis, and elevation of serum uric acid levels. It carries the black-box warnings, and use should be limited to no more than 2 years and avoided in patients who are at increased baseline risk for osteosarcoma

questions.text: Which one of the following drug drugs should never be used with Lithium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lisinopril due to the fact that lisinopril is 100% renally cleared. Lisinopril accumulates in those with subnormal renal function, and the steadily increasing lisinopril levels lead to higher Li+ levels, Lisinopril should never be used with Li+; any other ACEI can be used with dosing adjustment based on levels.
Distal collecting tubule diuretics cause Na+ wasting and thereby increase reabsorption of Li+ proximally. Among the commonly used agents in this class, the thiazides present the greatest risk and must be avoided. Amiloride causes less Na+ wasting and can be used to manage Li+-related polyuria.  Loop diuretics such as furosemide decrease Li+ clearance only approximately 20% in healthy younger individuals and are the diuretics of choice for most patients on Li+.
Through alteration of renal perfusion, some nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents can facilitate renal proximal tubular resorption of Li+ and thereby increase serum concentrations. This interaction appears to be particularly prominent with indomethacin, but also may occur with ibuprofen, naproxen, meloxicam, ketorolac, and COX-2 inhibitors, and less so with sulindac and aspirin.

It is indicated as oral monotherapy for adults with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria. was approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for the treatment of adults with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria in December 2023
 Pegcetacoplan- a pegylated peptide targeting proximal complement protein C3, potentially inhibits both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis
Eculizumab & ravulizumab-  inhibits the terminal, lytic pathway of complement by blocking the activation of the complement protein C5

questions.text: A young man sustains major soft tissue injury and open fractures of his right leg after a motorcycle accident. One day later, he has a temperature of 38°C, increased heart rate, sweating, and restlessness. On examination, the leg is swollen and tense, with thin, dark serous fluid draining from the wounds. The skin of the leg is cool, pale, white, and shining. Crepitus can be felt in the leg. His hematocrit is 20% (∼50% of normal), and his circulating hemoglobin is normal. His serum shows free hemoglobin. which of the followingis likely to be responsible for the hemolysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

The alpha toxin of C. perfringens type A is a lecithinase, and its lethal action is proportionate to therate at which it splits lecithin (an important constituent of cell membranes) to phosphorylcholine and diglyceride. 
Alpha toxin also aggregates platelets, thereby leading to formation of thrombi in small blood vessels and adding to poor tissueprofusion and extending the consequences of anaerobiosis, namely, destruction of viable tissue (gas gangrene).

questions.text: Pathologic effects of filariae in humans are caused by the adult worms in all but one species. In this case, the principal damage is caused by the microfilariae of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) O. volvulus infections are transmitted when infected black flies of the genus Simulium feed on human skin. Black flies require fast-flowing rivers and well-oxygenated waters to breed, hence the name for the disease: “river blindness. With Onchocerca, it is the microfilariae released from the female worms that cause the most severe damage. Migrating microfilariae, exclusively found in the interstitial fluids of the skin and subdermal tissues (not the bloodstream), cause changes in skin pigment and loss of elastic fibers, leading to “hanging groin,” other skin changes, and severe pruritus, sometimes intractable and intolerable.

questions.text: What is a defining characteristic of a nested case-control study compared to a traditional case-control study?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cases and controls are pre-defined within an established cohort in nested case-control studies
Explanation
Advanced Cohort Study: Case Control Studies Based in A defined Cohort
Properties:
•    Predominantly a type of cohort study (due to a forward direction)
•    Advantages:
•    Problem of recall bias is eliminated
•    Advantage of temporality is maintained
•    Economical (Done for rare diseases + whose diagnostic tests are very expensive)
•    Greater comparability (as both cases & controls are derived from the original cohort)
•    Disadvantage: non diseased persons from whom the controls are selected may not be fully representative of original cohort, due to death or failure to follow up cases
Types:

Indirect laryngoscopy permits examination of structures of the oropharynx, larynx and laryngopharynx.

He is asked to protrude his tongue which is wrapped in gauze and held by the examiner between the thumb and middle finger. Index finger is used to keep the upper lip or moustache out of the way

• Larynx. Epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, arytenoids, cuneiform and corniculate cartilages, ventricular bands,ventricles, true cords, anterior commissure, posterior commissure, subglottis and rings of trachea.

• Laryngopharynx. Both pyriform fossae, postcricoid region, posterior wall of laryngopharynx.

• Oropharynx. Base of tongue, lingual tonsils, valleculae, medial and lateral glossoepiglottic folds.

Ref: Read the text below Sol: Causes for pooling of saliva in the pyriform fossa: Pooling of saliva in the pyriform fossa is not only caused by growth affecting this area causing obstruction to saliva being swallowed, but also due to intense cricopharyngeal muscle spasm. • Malignant growth involving the deep portion of the pyriform fossa • Foreign body being lodged in the pyriform fossa. • Growth involving the crico pharynx (Postcricoid) or upper oesophagus can also cause pooling of saliva.

questions.text: A man is using nasal drops continuously for last 4-5 years. Choose the most possible adverse effect from its use?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Rhinitis Medicamentosa Ref: Read the text below Sol: • Continuous use of nasal decongestants for a long period of time result in severe mucosal edema, hyperemia, and nasal obstruction. On physical examination, the nasal mucosa will be thickened, erythematous, and edematous and will lack appreciable decongestion on topical decongestant application. • Treatment of this condition includes complete cessation of the offending agent, followed by the use of nasal saline lavage and nasal topical steroids. • Use of oral decongestants and a course of oral corticosteroids may help hasten symptom resolution and increase patient compliance. • Resolution usually takes 3–4 weeks. • Complications of untreated rhinitis medicamentosa include poor healing after nasal surgery, septal perforation, and formation of synechiae.

Sol:
•    Nasopharynx cancer or nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) is the most common cancer originating in the nasopharynx, the uppermost region of the pharynx ("throat"), behind the nose where the nasal passages and auditory tubes join the remainder of the upper respiratory tract. NPC occurs in children and adults.
•    NPC differs significantly from other cancers of the head and neck in its occurrence, causes, clinical behavior, and treatment. 
•    It is vastly more common in certain regions of East Asia and Africa than elsewhere, with viral, dietary and genetic factors implicated in its causation. It is most common in males. It is a squamous cell carcinoma or an undifferentiated type. 
•    Squamous cells are a flat type of cell found in the skin and the membranes that line some body cavities. Differentiation means how different the cancer cells are from normal cells. 
•    Undifferentiated is a word used to describe cells that do not have their mature features or functions.
•    Cervical lymphadenopathy (disease or swelling of the lymph nodes in the neck) is the initial presentation in many patients, and the diagnosis of NPC is often made by lymph node biopsy. Symptoms related to the primary tumor include trismus, pain, otitis media, nasal regurgitation due to paresis (loss of or impaired movement) of the soft palate, hearing loss and cranial nerve palsies (paralysis). 
•    Larger growths may produce nasal obstruction or bleeding and a "nasal twang". Metastatic spread may result in bone pain or organ dysfunction. Rarely, a paraneoplastic syndrome of osteoarthropathy (diseases of joints and bones) may occur with widespread disease.

Investigations reveal TLC of 21000, Urea of 8.5 and x-ray reveals consolidation in the right lung. She is treated for CAP. Which of the following is the correct calculated CURB 65 score?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Total score is 4. CURB65 criteria is a prognostic score for cases of community acquired pneumonia. It is provided by BTS (British Thorasic society) It consists of following parameters, the presence of each is given 1 point. The maximum score possible is 5. questions.text: A 38-year-old woman has Bout onset multiple sclerosis. She has experienced two attacks of disease previously that have left her with residual lower extremity weakness. She was initially treated with glucocorticoids with some improvement in her symptoms. However, she is currently only able to walk with a rolling walker about 100 m. A prior antibody test shows that she is positive for reactivity to the JC virus. You are planning to start a disease-modifying therapy. Which of the following is LEAST appropriate for this individual?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Natalizumab is not recommended in this patient due to the presence of antibody to JC virus. About half of the population is antibody positive for JC virus, indicating past exposure typically with an asymptomatic infection. JC virus is implicated in the development of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy. This life-threatening condition has occurred in 0.3% of all patients treated with natalizumab and in about 0.6% of patients who are positive for JC virus antibody. The risk is lower in the first year of treatment and increases thereafter. Thus, natalizumab should not be used in this patient unless she has failed alternative therapies or if the disease course has been particularly aggressive.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female non-smoker presented with sudden onset of cough followed by breathlessness. CXR revealed pneumothorax. She also gives history of similar episodes in the past. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pulmonary LAM • Pulmonary Lymphangioleiomyomatosis is a rare, progressive and systemic disease that typically results in cystic lung destruction. • It predominantly affects women, especially during childbearing years. • It is a neoplasm of smooth muscle spindle. • Majority present with shortness of breath with recurrent spontaneous pneumothorax in a non-smoker female. • Sirolimus is an mTOR inhibitor that stabilizes lung function and improves some measures of life in LAM patients. • Lung transplant offers potential cure but there is a risk of recurrence in the graft making the overall prognosis poor.

questions.text: A post-menopausal female presented with sudden onset angina. Coronary Angiography revealed normal vessels. Ventriculography performed in this patient during systole revealed the following picture. What is the probable diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy – Stress induced cardiomyopathy (Broken Heart syndrome) is a unknown etiology transient myocardial ischemia syndrome common in postmenopausal females especially after intense emotional stimulus. Patients often present with chest pain, have ST-segment elevation on electrocardiography (ECG), and have elevated cardiac enzyme levels consistent with myocardial infarction (MI). However, when the patient undergoes cardiac angiography, left ventricular (LV) apical ballooning (as seen in the Question image – Takotsubo) is present, and there is no significant coronary artery stenosis.

The Japanese word takotsubo translates to "octopus pot," resembling the shape of the left ventricle during systole on imaging studies.

questions.text: An 80 years old man with past history of AMI is found to have LBBB on ECG. He is asymptomatic; on cardiac auscultation the most likely finding is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Second heart sound (S2) is composed of aortic closure followed by pulmonic closure. Because inspiration increases blood return to the right side of heart, pulmonic closure is delayed which results in normal splitting of S2 during inspiration. Paradoxical or reverse splitting of S2 refers to narrowed splitting of S2 during inspiration as compared with expiration because pulmonic closure precedes aortic closure. It can occur in the following - LBBB, Aortic stenosis, HOCM, severe hypertension, and RV pacemaker.

questions.text:
Interpret the following ABG:
ph – 7.23
PaCO2 – 70 mm
HCO3 – 25 mEq
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Acute Respiratory Acidosis The ABG shows Primary Respiratory acidosis. To differentiate we need to look at the relation to change in pH with change in PaCO2 in Acute vs Chronic disease. In Acute Respiratory acidosis, there is no time for Metabolic compensation (which occurs over weeks to months) and hence the drop in pH is 0.4 for every 10mm increase in PaCO2. In Chronic Respiratory acidosis, there is time for Metabolic compensation (which occurs over weeks to months) and hence the drop in pH is 0.1 for every 10mm increase in PaCO2.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a 6-year history of HIV-AIDS complicated recently by PCP was treated with high dose Co-Trimoxazole. On day 4 of treatment, the following laboratory data was obtained as follows: Na+ -135, K+-6.5, Cl-110, HCO3-15, pH-7.30, BUN-14, Creatinine-0.9, Plasma Osmolarity - 268. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Non-Anion gap metabolic acidosis: One of the causes is Drug induced due to competitive inhibition of aldosterone by Trimethoprim (Part of cotrimoxazole) leading to Type 4 RTA. Step wise approach : 1.pH is 7.30= acidosis 2.HCO3 is 15(low); pH and Hco3 change same direction= metabolic acidosis 3.AG (Anion Gap) = (Na+) - (Cl- + HCO3--) = 135-(110+15)=10; normal anion gap.

choices.text: Metabolic Acidosis with Compensatory respiratory Alkalosis
Metabolic Acidosis with Additional Respiratory Acidosis
Metabolic Acidosis with Additional Respiratory Alkalosis
Respiratory alkalosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis

questions.text:
Interpret the following ABG:
ph – 7.20
PaO2 – 69mm
PaCO2 – 30 mm
HCO3 – 15 mEq
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Metabolic Acidosis with Compensatory respiratory Alkalosis Compensation in case of Metabolic acidosis i.e. expected change in CO2 due to acidosis is calculated using Winter’s formula: (1.5*Pts HCO3 value) + 8 +/- 2. In the given question, the ph is 7.20 indicating acidosis. (Hence NOT Option D) HCO3 is less than normal indicating Primary Metabolic acidosis. According to Winter’s formula: Expected PaCO2 in this patient should be 30+/-2 mm. Since the PaCO2 in the report is as expected, there is no additional respiratory defect and the change in PaCO2 (i.e. Respirator Alkalosis) is compensatory to the primary defect.

choices.text: Normal–anion-gap metabolic acidosis + High anion gap acidosis

questions.text: An 84-year-old female was found to have a blood pressure of 85/60 mmHg, heart rate 101beats/min, temperature 37.8°C. Laboratory data are obtained: sodium 137 meq/L, potassium 2.8meq/L, HCO3 10 meq/L, chloride 117 meq/L, BUN 17 mg/dL, creatinine 0.9 mg/dL. An arterial blood gas shows PaO2 80 mmHg, PCO2 24 mmHg, pH 7.29. Her urine analysis is clear and has a Ph of 4.5. What is the acid-base disorder?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) NAGMA and compensatory respiratory alkalosis. Steps in ABG: 1. See the pH: Acidosis or Alkalosis 2. Check for primary disorder: Respiratory or metabolic 3. See for compensation. a.IF primary was respiratory process , calculate metabolic compensation. If primary was metabolic calculate respiratory compensation b. If given value is within the expected value then it is a simple acid base disorder c. If given value is not correlating with expected value then it will be a inappropriate compensation / mixed disorder. 4. Calculate Anion gap In given case, Acidosis is correlating more to fall in HCO3 so its metabolic acidosis. Expected PaCO2 = [1.5 × HCO3] +8 +-2 that give the value of 21 to 25mmhg. Here the given PaCO2 is correlating with expected value which will suggest metabolic acidosis and compensatory alkalosis. Anion gap is also with in normal range (10-12meq)

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of Lactic Acidosis- Type A?

Malignancy, Drug use (NNRTI in HIV), Drug toxicity (Methanol, polyethylene glycol,etc), Thiamine deficiency, DM, Renal failure,etc can also cause Lactic acidosis without anaerobic state. These are classified as Lactic acidosis – Type B.

PCWP is < 20mm of Hg as it is a pre-capillary cause. PAH can also occur along with HIV, Autoimmune disease and Drug use. In Scleroderma, PAH is a dreaded complication. questions.text: A 12 years old boy presented with midline swelling in upper neck. The swelling moves up with deglutition and with protrusion of the tongue. Which of the following is TRUE statement.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Thyroglossal duct cysts result from retention of an epithelial tract between the thyroid and its embryologic origin in the foramen cecum at the base of the tongue. This tract usually penetrates the hyoid bone. There is no sex predilection, and although these cysts are more frequently detected in children, up to 25% do not become symptomatic until adulthood. The most common presentation is a painless swelling in the midline of the neck that moves with protrusion of the tongue or swallowing. The cysts are prone to infection and progressive enlargement. Although rare (less than 1%), epidermoid or papillary carcinomas do occur within thyroglossal duct cysts. Surgical resection is the standard therapy. The Sistrunk procedure, which involves local resection of the cyst and the central portion of the hyoid bone, is the operation of choice. Simple excision of the cyst results in an unacceptably high recurrence rate.

choices.text: It is faster growing than the epidermoid form.

questions.text: Verrucous carcinoma of the buccal mucosa is identified with which of the following characteristics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Verrucous carcinoma is a less aggressive form of locally invasive buccal cancer than the usual epidermoid form. Its frequency is increased in people who chew tobacco. The tumor usually grows very slowly, occurs chiefly in the gingivobuccal gutter, and can invade bone. It is identified by its characteristic exophytic, white, shaggy appearance. Wide excision is the best initial treatment for this neoplasm. It is a locally aggressive tumour and rarely metastasize to regional lymph nodes or to distant sites.
Cervical metastases usually are not present when the lesion is first diagnosed; it is only for the most highly malignant grades of verrucous carcinoma that radical neck dissection and block excision of the cheek are indicated.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man is admitted to the emergency following a motorcycle accident. He is alert and fully oriented, but witnesses to the accident report an interval of unresponsiveness following the injury. Skull films disclose a fracture of the left temporal bone. Following x-ray, the patient suddenly loses consciousness and dilation of the left pupil is noted. This patient is most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Epidural hematomas are typically caused by a tear of the middle meningeal artery or vein or a dural venous sinus. Ninety percent of epidural hematomas are associated with linear skull fractures, usually in the temporal region. Only 2% of patients admitted with craniocerebral trauma suffer epidural hematomas. The lesion appears as a hyperdense biconvex mass between the skull and brain on CT scan. Clinical presentation is highly variable and outcome largely depends on promptness of diagnosis and surgical evacuation. The typical history is one of head trauma followed by a momentary alteration in consciousness and then a lucid interval lasting for up to a few hours. This is followed by a loss of consciousness, dilation of the pupil on the side of the epidural hematoma, and then compromise of the brainstem and death. Treatment consists of temporal craniectomy, evaluation of the hemorrhage, and control of the bleeding vessel. The mortality of epidural hematoma is approximately 50%.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding hypospadias is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hypospadias is a common congenital anomaly of the penis resulting from incomplete development of the anterior urethra. It occurs in about 1 in 300 live births. Hypospadias occurs in the corona in about 75% of cases, where it is often accompanied by chordee, hooded prepuce and bifid glans. Undescended testes occur in about 10% of cases of hypospadias, as do inguinal hernias. Hypospadias in the scrotal area is associated with bilateral undescended testes and must be differentiated from pseudohermaphroditism and adrenogenital syndrome.
Most common type is anterior (Glandular and coronal) for which MAGPAI procedure can be done.

questions.text: The initial treatment for stage 1 of  TCC bladder is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bladder cancer represents 2% of all cancers, and 90% of bladder cancers are of transitional cell origin. It is most prevalent among men with a heavy smoking history and is usually multifocal and superficial, even when recurrent. When the disease is still superficial, transurethral resection of visible lesions followed by intravesical BCG (for CIS) or chemotherapy (for T1) are most often recommended. 
More radical surgical extirpation like radical cystectomy is reserved for advanced stages of the disease like muscle invasion or node positive cancer.

questions.text: A patient has bronchogenic carcinomas of lung. Shown in picture. Which of the following is following clinical features is most probable in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pancoast tumors are peripheral bronchogenic carcinomas that produce symptoms by involvement of extrapulmonary structures adjacent to the cupula. These structures include the nerve roots of C8 and T1, as well as the sympathetic trunk. Interruption of the cervical sympathetic trunk leads to miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis, the triad of signs that constitutes Horner syndrome. Involvement of the nerve roots causes pain along the corresponding dermatomes. The peripheral location of the neoplasm makes pulmonary signs, such as atelectasis, cough, and hemoptysis, unlikely.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the hospital with a 24-h history of abdominal pain of the right lower quadrant. She undergoes an uncomplicated appendectomy for acute appendicitis and is discharged home on the fourth postoperative day. The pathologist notes the presence of a carcinoid tumor (1.2 cm) in the tip of the appendix. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Carcinoid tumors arise from the neuroectoderm and are a type of apudoma. The most common site of carcinoid tumors is the small bowel, although appendiceal carcinoids are also common. Carcinoid syndrome, which is characterized by flushing, diarrhea, and cardiac valvular disease, occurs in a small percentage of patients with carcinoid tumors; it is rarely seen with appendiceal carcinoids. It occurs when serotonin is released into the systemic circulation and thus avoids breakdown by the liver. The appropriate therapy for a small carcinoid (less than 2 cm) at the tip of the appendix is simple appendectomy.

questions.text: Most commonly used radio-isotope in High Dose Radiation in Carcinoma prostate is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Brachytherapy for prostate can be HDR (High dose radiotherapy) or LDR (Low dose radiotherapy). In HRD a temporary implant is placed in prostate which is removed after for 10-20 mins while in LRD a permanent implant in kept in prostate

LDR procedures use low-energy radiation sources, most commonly iodine 125 (125I) or palladium 103 (103Pd). 
Iridium 192 (192Ir), the most common HDR brachytherapy source 
Indication for brachytherapy in prostate cancer are-

PSA level is between 10 and 20 ng/ml,
Gleason score is < 7, 
Stage of your cancer is < T2b.
Prostate volume of approximately 20-60 cc 
EBRT is preferred if

PSA level is higher than 20 ng/ml, or
Gleason score is 8, 9 or 10, or
Stage of your cancer is T2c, T3 or T4.
Brachytherapy is not a good treatment option for patients with significant baseline obstructive uropathy. 
exclude patients with a baseline American Urologic Association (AUA) symptom score > 15 if already on medication, or > 20 if previously untreated for obstructive symptoms.

questions.text: False statement about abdominal trauma is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

(First investigation is CEC is stable and FAST in unstable patient)

Evaluation of haemodynamically stable blunt abdominal trauma
•    Haemodynamically stable patients with no complaints of abdominal pain, a non-tender abdomen, and a reliable physical examination (i.e., no distracting injuries, no head injury) though may not require CT but absence of abdominal tenderness does not rule out possibility of intra-abdominal injury.
•    An abdominal CT scan is recommended to evaluate for associated intra-abdominal injury. 
•    Patients with abdominal tenderness, abdominal wall contusions, or an unreliable physical examination due to head injury, intoxication, or a distracting injury require further investigation with "FAST" (focused assessment with sonography for trauma) or an abdominal CT scan to diagnose potential intra-abdominal injury. 
•    FAST has the highest likelihood ratio for the presence of intra-abdominal injury. 
•    A CT scan of the abdomen is highly sensitive for the diagnosis of solid organ injury, vascular injury, and pelvic fractures, and is the radiographic study of choice to rule out intra-abdominal injury. It is less effective in the diagnosis of diaphragmatic or bowel injuries. 
•    The presence of free intraperitoneal fluid on an abdominal CT scan, without evidence of a solid organ injury, raises concern of a hollow organ injury. In this group of patients, diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) may be useful.
•    DPL involves making a small midline incision below the umbilicus and using a needle and small catheter to aspirate intraperitoneal fluid to assess for blood or bile. 
•    If the aspirate (DPA) is found to contain 10 mL of gross blood or bile, an exploratory laparotomy is indicated. In the absence of gross blood or bile, DPL requires 1 litre of fluid to be infused into the peritoneum and then drained. The effluent should be sent to the laboratory and evaluated. Laboratory criteria for a positive DPL are:
•    >100,000 red blood cells/mm^3
•    >500 white blood cells/mm^3
•    Presence of bacteria, bile, or food particles.
•    DPL in stable patients has limited utility. If a follow-up abdominal CT scan is performed, the additional fluid in the abdomen secondary to DPL can confuse the picture. In stable patients, DPL is an excellent adjunctive study when in an obtunded patient who has free fluid on abdominal CT scanning with no solid organ injury identified. 
•    A patient with blunt abdominal trauma haemodynamically stable but have evidence of some intra-abdominal solid organ bleeding on abdominal CT should be followed as inpatients, with serial abdominal examinations and Hct levels to observe for continued bleeding. 
•    If there is a steady decline in the Hct level, blood transfusion or intervention to control the bleeding may be required. 

Evaluation of haemodynamically unstable blunt abdominal trauma
•    In haemodynamically unstable patients with blunt abdominal trauma, evaluation and resuscitation occur concurrently. 
•    The goal of evaluation is to determine the site of bleeding and at the same time initiate appropriate therapy for control of the bleeding. 
•    Radiographs performed in the trauma suite are useful to rule out a haemothorax or pelvic fracture. A focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) examination is useful to quickly diagnose intra-abdominal haemorrhage. 
•    The FAST examination uses a bedside ultrasound to provide images of the RUQ, LUQ, and pelvis to assess for intra-abdominal haemorrhage. 
•    A systematic review found that the presence of intraperitoneal fluid or organ injury on ultrasound is more accurate than any history and physical examination findings in the diagnostic evaluation for intra-abdominal injuries after blunt abdominal trauma. If a FAST examination is unavailable or unreliable, a DPL may be performed to assess for intraperitoneal bleeding. 
•    Patients found to have significant free intra-abdominal fluid according to FAST examination (or DPL) and haemodynamic instability are recommended to undergo urgent surgery. 

Evaluation of penetrating abdominal trauma
•    The majority of cases of penetrating abdominal trauma are related to gunshot wounds (GSWs) and stab wounds. 
•    Patients presenting with signs of peritonitis, or haemodynamic instability, require an urgent laparotomy. 
•    Those with stab wounds to the abdominal wall require local wound exploration under Local anaesthesia to evaluate for perforation of the abdominal wall fascia. 
•    If the anterior fascia has not been violated, it is safe to assume that the intra-abdominal organs have not been injured. 
•    Patients with wounds that penetrate the abdominal fascia require further evaluation and close observation with serial abdominal examinations, laparoscopy to rule out intra-abdominal organ injury, or immediate laparotomy.  
•    Stab wounds to the flank or back require a CT scan to rule out to colonic, splenic, or kidney. 
•    Gunshot wounds to the abdomen are typically managed operatively regardless of the clinical status of the patient. 
•    Plain films of the chest and abdomen with metallic markers (e.g., paper clip) over entrance and exit wounds (if present) should be urgently ordered to determine the trajectory of the bullet. 
•    It is important to rule out chest injuries prior to surgical exploration of the abdomen.

questions.text: A 31 year old female complains of Anterior Knee Pain with difficulty in squatting and cross legged sitting for long periods. An illustration is attached hereby. Which of the following is not true about this ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A. Cinema Sign is clinically seen in these patients: This statement is True. "Cinema Sign" (or theater sign) refers to the experience of anterior knee pain and stiffness after prolonged sitting with knees bent, a common symptom in patients with Chondromalacia Patellae.

B. There is no Osteochondral fragment seen initially: This statement is generally True. Chondromalacia Patellae primarily involves softening and degeneration of the articular cartilage on the undersurface of the patella. It does not typically involve the initial formation or presence of osteochondral (bone and cartilage) fragments. Fragments are more common in osteochondritis dissecans or advanced degenerative changes.

C. It is Chondromalacia Patellae which needs surgical management in most of the cases: This statement is False. Chondromalacia Patellae is often managed conservatively with physical therapy, pain management, activity modification, and bracing. Surgical intervention (like arthroscopic debridement or realignment procedures) is typically reserved for cases that do not respond to extensive conservative treatment, and thus, it is not required in most cases.

D. Arthroscopic Biopsy is a must for diagnosis: This statement is False. The diagnosis of Chondromalacia Patellae is primarily clinical, based on symptoms (anterior knee pain, crepitus, pain with specific activities like squatting or climbing stairs) and physical examination findings. Imaging like X-rays (to rule out other bone issues) or MRI (to assess cartilage status) can support the diagnosis. Arthroscopy is an invasive procedure and a biopsy is generally not a must for diagnosis; it's typically performed for treatment (e.g., debridement) or if the diagnosis remains unclear after non-invasive methods.

questions.text: All of the following are not true about suicide except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Asking about suicide will often reduce the anxiety surrounding the feeling MYTHS ABOUT SUICIDE

Risk factors for suicide:
1.    Previous suicide attempt (most imp)
2.    Family history of suicide
3.    Male gender
4.    Family history of child abuse
5.    History of mental disorders, particularly clinical depression
6.    History of alcohol and substance abuse
7.    Feelings of hopelessness
8.    Impulsive or aggressive tendencies
9.    Cultural and religious beliefs (e.g., belief that suicide is noble resolution of a personal dilemma)
10.    Local epidemics of suicide
11.    Isolation, a feeling of being cut off from other people
12.    Living alone
13.    Barriers to accessing mental health treatment
14.    Loss (relational, social, work, or financial)
15.    Physical illness
16.    Easy access to lethal methods
17.    Unwillingness to seek help because of the stigma attached to mental health and substance abuse disorders or to suicidal thoughts

Correct Answer (A)

The findings of subpleural and basal-predominant reticulation with honeycombing and no atypical features permit a confident diagnosis of usual interstitial pneumonia, the pattern of interstitial fibrosis occurring in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: 28-year-old male patient with fever and right upper quadrant pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hepatic amebic abscesses are usually solitary or few, with a shaggy wall, and are endemic in certain populations, all features that are seen in this case.

questions.text: The first sign of puberty in females is typically:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Thelarche is the first sign of puberty in girls

choices.text: Obtaining a CBC and iron studies.

questions.text: A mother brings her 17-year-old son for his annual health maintenance exam. When you ask if she has any concerns about him, she mentions that he sleeps all the time. She also states that he was always a happy child but recently has become more withdrawn and always seems tired. She reports that his grades have been declining, and he does not seem to enjoy activities he previously enjoyed, such as playing soccer and video games with friends. The next step in diagnosing this patient is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

HEADSSS was developed as a psychosocial screening  tool:
H- Home (Who lives with the teen? How does the teen get along with family?)
E - Education (Is the teen in school ? How is he or she performing in school? School performance can be  important indication of how a teen is functioning .)
E- Eating (meal consistency; body image)
A - Activities
D- Drugs (alcohol, tobacco, marijuana, and other drug use, including prescription and over-the-counter)
S - Sexuality 
S- Suicide/Depression
S - Safety (Does the teen feel safe at home or school?)

questions.text: A 2 months old child has edema and tachycardia On examination, he has cardiomegaly with a cardiothoracic ratio of 0.67. Which vitamin deficiency can cause this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Beriberi
Infantile beriberi — Beriberi in infants becomes clinically apparent between the ages of two and three months and mainly affects infants who are breastfed by mothers with a thiamine-deficient diet. The clinical features are variable and may include a fulminant cardiac syndrome with cardiomegaly, tachycardia, a loud piercing cry, cyanosis, dyspnea, vomiting and pulmonary hypertension. Older infants may have neurologic symptoms resembling aseptic meningitis, including agitation, an aphonic (soundless) cry, vomiting, nystagmus, purposeless movements, altered consciousness, and seizure, with no abnormalities on cerebrospinal fluid analysis. Treatment for acute forms is with parenterally administered thiamine, using doses in infants of 100 to 150 mg, typically leading to rapid improvement of symptoms.

questions.text: Perioral rash, diarrhea, alopecia, frequent infections in a one year old child should raise suspicion of deficiency of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Zinc
Numerous signs and symptoms have been associated with zinc depletion. Mild zinc deficiency is associated with depressed immunity, impaired taste and smell, onset of night blindness, decreased spermatogenesis, and, sometimes, a mild psoriasiform dermatitis. Severe zinc deficiency is characterized by dermatitis (typically erythematous, scaly, vesiculobullous, or pustular lesions in the perioral and perianal areas or on extensor surfaces of the limbs), severely depressed immune function, frequent infections, diarrhea, and alopecia.

questions.text: Which of the following would make Turner syndrome an unlikely diagnosis in a patient with amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The hypothalamus and pituitary function normally but the ovary does not, so FSH and LH are elevated.

questions.text: The most common inherited bleeding disorder, which often presents as menorrhagia in adolescent females is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
 
The most common inherited bleeding disorder in the United States population is von Willebrand disease, with an estimated prevalence of 1 % to 2%.

Which immunodeficiency is not correctly matched with its
mode of inheritance?

The correct answer is "B:' AT is an autosomal recessive condition.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl injured her knee after skiing at Gulmarg. She saw her primary care physician who advised rest and icing, as well as ibuprofen if needed for pain. Thirty minutes after taking 400 mg of ibuprofen, she develops diffuse hives and swelling of her lips and eyelids. Alarmed, her family rushes her to the emergency department, where on arrival she vomits, feels short of breath, and is lightheaded. What medication should be administered first to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The correct answer is ''A:' Anaphylaxis is a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction with IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation involving multiorgan systems. First-line treatment for anaphylaxis is epinephrine-every time. If the first round of epinephrine is ineffective at fully reversing symptoms, a second round of epinephrine should be administered. Dosing for epinephrine is 0.01 mg/kg intramuscular of a 1 : 1000 solution. Early administration of epinephrine reduces mortality associated with anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Which is NOT a laboratory finding of acute tumor lysis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 
The correct answer is "A:' Findings of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) can include hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia, and hypocalcemia (secondary to precipitation of calcium phosphate) . For these reasons, any patient with a suspected diagnosis of a hematologic malignancy should be screened for these changes, and treated immediately for any abnormal findings.

choices.text: Absence of radii on upper extremity X-rays.
Marked decrease in megakaryocytes on bone marrow aspirate.
Mutation in WAS gene on genetic testing.
Hyperpigmentation and microcephaly on physical exam.

questions.text: A term baby boy is found on day of life 1 to have petechiae in his antecubital and popliteal fossae, and around the base of the neck. A CBC reveals a platelet count of 13 x 103/mm and the platelets appear small in size on blood smear evaluation. Family history reveals that the patient has two brothers, ages 6 and 2 years; the older brother has eczema, frequent nose bleeds, bruises easily, and has been admitted to the hospital several times with bacterial pneumonia, while the other brother is healthy. The patient's mother has no chronic illness; her older brother died as a teenager from prolonged bleeding following a motorcycle accident. Which of the following additional findings would you anticipate in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The correct answer is "C:' This patient presents with congenital microthrombocytopenia and an X-linked inheritance pattern with family history of atopic disease and immunodeficiency, all consistent with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) . WAS is caused by a defective WAS protein, which participates in cytoskeletal connections that are essential for platelet and leukocyte function. The classic diagnostic triad for WAS is thrombocytopenia, immunodeficiency, and eczema. The platelets in WAS are small in size. Neonates with WAS are at increased risk of significant hemorrhage and merit support with platelet transfusion. Because of the substantial risk of life-threatening bleeding or infection, long-term management includes hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) if a suitable donor is available.
